name: flag
content:
flag

noun
 
 
/flæɡ/
 
/flæɡ/
Idioms
jump to other results
  1. enlarge image
     
     a piece of cloth with a special coloured design on it that may be the symbol of a particular country or organization, may be used to give a signal or may have a particular meaning. A flag can be attached to a pole (= a long thin straight piece of wood or metal) or held in the hand.
    • the Italian flag
    • the flag of Italy
    • The hotel flies the European Union flag.
    • The American flag was flying.
    • Hundreds of people cheered and waved flags.
    • All the flags were at half mast (= in honour of a famous person who has died).
    • The black and white flag went down, and the race began.
    • The assistant referee had raised his flag for offside.
    • A large Brazilian flag fluttered above the podium.
    • His shot went closer to the corner flag than the goal.
    • Australia's flag bearer (= person who carried the flag) at the Sydney Olympics
    see also black flag, blue flag, chequered flag, red flag, white flag
    Extra Examples
    • A tattered flag hung from the roof of the burnt-out building.
    • The crowd all waved flags as the president came past.
    • The fact that it was so cheap should have been a warning flag for me.
    • a flag fluttering in the breeze
    • a flag of truce
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • national
    • battle
    • burning
    • …
    verb + flag
    • fly
    • hang
    • hang out
    • …
    flag + verb
    • hang
    • flap
    • flutter
    • …
    flag + noun
    • pole
    preposition
    • under a/​the flag
    • flag of
    phrases
    • flag of convenience
    • flag of surrender
    See full entry
  2. used to refer to a particular country or organization and its beliefs and values
    • to swear allegiance to the flag
    • under a flag The team competed under the Olympic flag.
    • under the flag of something He was working under the flag of the United Nations.
  3. a flower that is a type of iris and that grows near water
    • yellow flags
    see also yellow flag
  4. (also flagstone)
     a large flat square piece of stone that is used for floors, paths, etc.
    5. Word Originnoun senses 1 to 3 mid 16th cent.: perhaps from obsolete flag ‘drooping’, of unknown ultimate origin. noun sense 5 late Middle English (also in the sense ‘turf, sod’): probably of Scandinavian origin and related to Icelandic flag ‘spot from which a sod has been cut’ and Old Norse flaga ‘slab of stone’. noun sense 4 late Middle English: related to Middle Dutch flag and Danish flæg; of unknown ultimate origin.
Idioms
fly/show/wave the flag
  1. to show your support for your country, an organization or an idea to encourage or persuade others to do the same
keep the flag flying
  1. to represent your country or organization
    • Our exporters keep the flag flying at international trade exhibitions.
like waving a red flag in front of a bull (US English)
(British English a red rag to a bull)
  1. something that is likely to make somebody very angry
See flag in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: flag

name: flag

flag

verb
 
/flæɡ/
 
/flæɡ/
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they flag
 
/flæɡ/
 
/flæɡ/
he / she / it flags
 
/flæɡz/
 
/flæɡz/
past simple flagged
 
/flæɡd/
 
/flæɡd/
past participle flagged
 
/flæɡd/
 
/flæɡd/
-ing form flagging
 
/ˈflæɡɪŋ/
 
/ˈflæɡɪŋ/
Phrasal Verbs
jump to other results
  1. [transitive] flag something to draw attention to information that you think is important, especially by putting a special mark next to it
    • I've flagged the paragraphs that we need to look at in more detail.
  2. [intransitive] to become tired, weaker or less enthusiastic
    • It had been a long day and the children were beginning to flag.
    • Her confidence had never flagged.
    • flagging support/enthusiasm

flagstone

jump to other results

name: flag day
content:
flag day

noun
 
/ˈflæɡ deɪ/
 
/ˈflæɡ deɪ/
jump to other results
  1. (British English) a day when money is collected in public places for a charity, and people who give money receive a small paper stickerTopics Social issuesc2
  2. Flag Day
     14 June, the anniversary of the day in 1777 when the Stars and Stripes became the national flag of the United States
Check pronunciation: flag day

name: flag off
content:
flag off

phrasal verb
jump to other results
flag something off
  1. (Indian English, West African English) to officially start an event
    • The tour was flagged off from Kashmir on 11 February.
    related noun flag-off

name: flag-off
content:
flag-off

noun
 
/ˈflæɡ ɒf/
 
/ˈflæɡ ɔːf/
(Indian English, West African English)
jump to other results
  1. the official start of an event
    • Thousands of people attended the flag-off in the capital city.
Check pronunciation: flag-off

name: flag up
content:
flag up

phrasal verb
jump to other results
flag something up
  1. (British English) to draw attention to something
    • The report flagged up the dangers of under-age drinking.

name: red flag
content:
red flag

noun
 
/ˌred ˈflæɡ/
 
/ˌred ˈflæɡ/
jump to other results
  1. a flag used to warn people of danger
    • You mustn’t swim when the red flag is flying.
    Topics Dangerc2
  2. a red flag as a symbol of revolution or communism
See red flag in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

matches: like waving a red flag in front of a bull
relatives: like waving a red flag in front of a bull

name: blue flag
content:
blue flag

noun
 
/ˌbluː ˈflæɡ/
 
/ˌbluː ˈflæɡ/
jump to other results
  1. (British English) a blue flag used in motor racing to show that a driver who is much further ahead is trying to pass
  2. an award given to beaches in Europe that are clean and safe
Check pronunciation: blue flag

name: flag down
content:
flag down

phrasal verb
jump to other results
flag somebody/something down
  1. to signal to the driver of a vehicle to stop by waving at them
    • She flagged down a passing motorist.
See flag down in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: black flag
content:
black flag

noun
 
/ˌblæk ˈflæɡ/
 
/ˌblæk ˈflæɡ/
jump to other results
  1. a black flag used in motor racing to stop a driver who has done something wrong
  2. a flag with a skull and crossbones on it

noun
 
/ˌwaɪt ˈflæɡ/
 
/ˌwaɪt ˈflæɡ/
 [usually singular]
jump to other results

name: yellow flag
content:
yellow flag

noun
 
/ˌjeləʊ ˈflæɡ/
 
/ˌjeləʊ ˈflæɡ/
jump to other results
  1. a type of yellow iris (= a flower) that grows near water
  2. a yellow flag on a ship showing that somebody has or may have an infectious disease (= one that can spread easily)

name: flag football
content:
flag football

noun
 
/ˌflæɡ ˈfʊtbɔːl/
 
/ˌflæɡ ˈfʊtbɔːl/
 [uncountable] (North American English)
jump to other results
  1. a type of American football played without the usual form of tackling. A tackle is made instead by pulling a piece of cloth from an opponent’s waistband. compare touch footballTopics Sports: ball and racket sportsc2
See flag football in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: flag football

name: The Red Flag
content:
The Red Flag

 
/ðə ˌred ˈflæɡ/
 
/ðə ˌred ˈflæɡ/
jump to other results
  1. the official song of the British Labour Party, written in 1889 by James Connell (1853-1929) and often sung at the end of large party meetings. The red flag is the international symbol of revolution and socialism. The song ends with its best-known line, ‘We'll keep the red flag flying here.’
Check pronunciation: The Red Flag

  1. a flag with black and white squares that is waved when a driver has finished a motor raceTopics Sports: other sportsc2
